SENT.plain: The immediate clinical course of 42 patients with cerebral embolism secondary to rheumatic heart disease (RHD) was analyzed retrospectively
All the cases included cranial computed tomographic (CT) findings
Twenty-five patients received early anticoagulant therapy (AT) and 17 did not
Recurrent embolic events occurred in only one case
Seven instances of hemorrhagic infarction (HI) were found
In five cases, the development of HI correlated with a recurrent stroke, which occurred in each case within 48 hours after the initial cerebral embolism
Three of the patients with HI died (all of them were receiving AT)
We believe that HI is a frequent cause of recurrent stroke after a cerebral embolic event, that it generally occurs in the first 48 hours, and that its outcome is possibly worsened by AT
Anticoagulant therapy should be delayed for three days after a cerebral embolic event secondary to RHD
